message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has significant carotid stenosis on the left, indicating a high risk for stroke. Left carotid endarterectomy is the most appropriate next step in management. Reassurance is not appropriate for a significant stenosis. Carotid artery stenting or bilateral endarterectomy may be considered, but the left-side stenosis is much more severe than the right and requires immediate attention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s physical examination shows systolic bruits over the neck bilaterally and ultrasonography shows stenosis on both sides. The left side has a higher level of stenosis which would put the patient at a higher risk of stroke, making left carotid endarterectomy the most appropriate next step in management. Reassurance is not appropriate in this case due to the presence of significant carotid stenosis. Carotid artery stenting and bilateral carotid endarterectomy are not appropriate as the degree of stenosis on the right is not severe enough to warrant intervention, and bilateral carotid endarterectomy may pose unnecessary risks for the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a significant carotid stenosis on the left side with symptoms such as systolic bruits over the neck bilaterally, and the duplex ultrasonography confirms the diagnosis. Therefore, left carotid endarterectomy is the most appropriate next step in management. Reassurance is not appropriate as the patient has a significant carotid stenosis. Carotid artery stenting is an option, but endarterectomy is the preferred treatment for significant stenosis. Bilateral carotid endarterectomy is not necessary as the right side only has a 55% stenosis, which does not meet the criteria for intervention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has significant carotid stenosis (≥70%) on the left side, and it is recommended to perform a carotid endarterectomy to reduce the risk of stroke. Reassurance is not appropriate as the patient has significant stenosis that requires intervention. Carotid artery stenting may be an alternative to endarterectomy, but it is not the most appropriate next step in management as it is less effective for high-risk patients. Bilateral carotid endarterectomy is not necessary as the stenosis on the right side is less severe.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of bilateral systolic bruits and carotid artery stenosis indicates a risk for stroke. Endarterectomy is recommended for symptomatic stenosis of greater than 50% and asymptomatic stenosis greater than 60%. In this case, there is an 85% stenosis on the left, so the most appropriate next step would be a left carotid endarterectomy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has significant carotid artery stenosis (above 70%) on the left and moderate stenosis on the right, and a history of smoking, which makes him at high risk for stroke. Left carotid endarterectomy is the most appropriate next step in management. Reassurance is not appropriate as the patient has significant stenosis. Carotid artery stenting and bilateral carotid endarterectomy are not necessary for the moderate stenosis on the right side.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s fasting serum studies show elevated LDL and decreased HDL, indicating a risk for atherosclerosis. The duplex ultrasonography shows significant stenosis on both left and right carotid arteries. This puts the patient at risk for stroke, making left carotid endarterectomy the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has significant carotid artery stenosis on the left side and a less significant stenosis on the right side, which increases his risk of stroke. Left carotid endarterectomy is the most appropriate next step in management. Reassurance is not appropriate as the patient has a significant risk of stroke. Carotid artery stenting or bilateral carotid endarterectomy may be considered in some cases, but the most appropriate option here is left carotid endarterectomy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has significant carotid artery stenosis, and left carotid endarterectomy is the most appropriate next step in management. Carotid artery stenting may be an option, but endarterectomy is actually preferred in cases of severe stenosis. Reassurance is not appropriate in this case, and bilateral carotid endarterectomy is not necessary for the level of stenosis observed on the right side.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has significant carotid stenosis which puts him at a high risk for a stroke. Thus, the most appropriate next step in management would be left carotid endarterectomy to remove the atherosclerotic plaque and improve blood flow to the brain. Reassurance is not sufficient given the high degree of stenosis. Carotid artery stenting may be an option but is generally reserved for cases where surgery is not feasible or has failed. Bilateral carotid endarterectomy is not indicated based on the degree of stenosis present.
